People think back to the Dotcom bubble, but it's not really comparable. There, you had a lot of no-name companies get huge valuations based on thin air and promises. Today, you have a handful of big, well-established companies with monster earnings who also have monster valuations. That's not a bubble. It might be due for a correction, but not anything like the Dotcom bust. Just think: If AI went away tomorrow, would Google and Nvidia, etc. be worthless? Fuck no. Also, AI will imo increase productivity. It already is. It can streamline a lot of monotonous tasks and free up the employee to do more innovative work. The concern is that moronic, greedy companies will think they can fully replace workers with AI, instead of letting their existing employees use it as a force multiplier. With that in mind, given the wave of recent layoffs, it does make sense to be short-term bearish. That doesn't mean they won't keep rising, though. (pro-tip:  nope, most AI implementations are not only half-baked but just make things harder.) I work in IT, installing and fixing servers and storage systems in datacenters for banks, insurance, financial companies, etc. and they're not installing a lot of AI hardware. An AI testbed demo here and there, but that's it. I know because I install and configure the damn things across about 50 datacenters in one metro alone. What are they installing if it's not AI?  STORAGE!  MASSIVE AMOUNTS OF STORAGE! And all of it is being managed by off-shored IT "management" companies based in India and those guys are fucking morons. And it's been that way for the at least the past 5 years and counting. What they're doing is contracting out anything-AI to the west coast and keeping the data stored in the midwest, south, and NE. If the west coast ever suffers a big power outage that lasts for a while, all that AI shit's going to start falling apart pretty quick. Why?  Because real AI datacenters have to be liquid-cooled and the vast majority of DCs in the USA are still not setup for liquid-cooling - it's all air-cooled.  Some try using dedicated hot-aisle/cold-aisle tricks but they almost always fail, especially when a DC fucks up and puts too many high-pressure, high-BTU server racks on the same aisle and it over-pressures the hot-aisle and starts blowing hot air back through the server racks into the cold-aisle.
